section-block.rac_essential-question: What can we do better together?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Ellen Tarlow Illustrated by Tomek Bogacki
section-block.rac_book_summary: Mole lives underground and wishes she could bring some of the sky into her home. Mole’s friends try to help her, but it’s harder than they thought! Find out what Mole does while also counting and subitizing images in the book.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: As a group, review rote counting to 10. Use Connecting Cubes to show that each number is one more than the previous number by connecting an additional cube for each number.
Sing “Five Green and Speckled Frogs” with children. As you sing, encourage children to hop like frogs in their spots. After you sing, review combinations of five.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read this book. What should we read on the cover?
The title is Mole Catches the Sky and it is written by Ellen Tarlow and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki.
Lala loves reading stories. Let’s see what this one is about!
Think about this question as we read and we’ll talk about it after we’re done reading. How do the animals try to catch the sky?
Who can show us how to hold a book to read it? Where should I start reading aloud from?
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: As you read the book, pause and have children count items on the pages.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Mole feel about being outside? What is her idea?
Squirrel says it will be light when Mole wakes up.
Why does Frog roll up a leaf? How many animal friends are shown?
What is Bird trying to bring to Mole’s home? How many friends do you see now?
How do Mole’s friends help her? (MB)
Let’s talk about the guiding question: How do the animals try to catch the sky?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about an underground home.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Squirrel try to hold part of the sky?
Squirrel tries to put the sky in a n____ (nutshell).
Squirrel tries to put the sky in a nutshell.
Do the animals catch the sky?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children with a different home language can benefit from multiple pre-reading activities, including preteaching relevant vocabulary and having children make predictions about the story. After reading, return to their predictions and determine if they were accurate.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Showing Empathy and Caring

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When your friends are sad, you might feel sad, too. This shows that you understand and care about your friends. You can show that you care about your friends by trying to make them happy. You might think of something they need or want and give it to them. You might also play with your friends or show how happy you are to see them.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages of Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. We will listen for how the animal friends care for each other.
Clifford cares about his friends and loves stories like this one that describes animal friends who care about each other.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Cardinality: Ask children, How many in all? as you read and count.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can show us how to hold the book today? Where do we start reading?
What is Mole doing with her claws?
How is Squirrel showing that he cares about Mole? (MB)
Without counting, how many friends are there?
How do you know that the animals care about Mole? (MB)
Were the animals able to bring handfuls of sky, light, and warmth to Mole’s underground home?
How did the animals know that Mole was sad? How do they show caring for Mole? (MB)
How did the animals work together? How does Mole feel now? How can you tell? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Show children pages 30–31 and point out that the friends are sharing breakfast in Mole’s house at the end of the story.

Invite children to pretend to make breakfast with you. Encourage children to suggest foods to include, like berries and nuts. For each item, place a Connecting Cube or Two-Color Counter onto a plate to represent the food.

As you add each item, point out that the number of items increases by one. When you are done “cooking,” count how many items there are altogether. Have a brief discussion about how you all worked together to make the breakfast.
Transcribe children’s sentences as they describe how Mole tried to catch the sky.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children become more aware of other people, they will start to recognize that others are sad or upset. Help children learn to express their concern directly to that person. Model words that they can use to communicate their concern. Explain that they might also offer physical comfort, such as a hug, if the friend agrees to it. (Denham and Burton, 2003)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Use the subitizing number cards to practice subitizing with children. Hold up the cards for the numbers one to five, and have children call out the number as fast as they can.
Give pairs of children a set of 10 Two-Color Counters with both sides showing. Have one count red first, then yellow; the other yellow first. Is the number in all the same?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki.
Lala loves reading stories about friends.
As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the animals try to bring Mole?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth discussion with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you think Mole’s underground home is like? Why would she want sky underground?
How does Squirrel try to catch the light for Mole?
How does Frog try to capture the warmth for Mole?
How does Bird try to hold the breeze? Why does she shut her beak?
Who goes down into Mole’s underground home? Let’s count the animals forward. Let’s count them backward.
How did Mole’s friends show that they understood Mole’s feelings? (MB)
How is Mole’s house different now? Do you like it better? Why?
How many friends are in Mole’s house? What makes the animals “good friends?”
Did you listen and remember as we read the book today? What do the animals try to bring Mole?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Squirrel tries to catch the light.
Frog tries to capture the warm sun.
Bird tries to capture the soft breeze.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about a time the children worked with someone else.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Frog try to bring to make Mole less cold?
Frog tries to bring Mole the w_____ (warm) sun.
Frog tries to bring Mole the warm sun.
Why do the animals try to bring Mole things?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Consistent practice of both perceptual and conceptual subitizing can boost children’s later mathematics skills. Perceptual subitizing is the ability to recognize the amount of items in a group without counting. Conceptual subitizing is the ability to add the groupings from their first perceptions together.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children two sets of blocks, one with three blocks and one with five. Challenge children to say which set has more without counting. Repeat with new numbers.
Point out that peas are one type of vegetable, and so are carrots, celery, and corn. Have children name as many other vegetables as they can.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read We Have Soup! It shows how working together can make things better.
We Have Soup! and Mole Catches the Sky each focus on ways to work together. Let’s look for more connections between the two!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Mole Catches the Sky book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can we do better together?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to We Can Do It
section.rac_body-text: Read the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where should I start reading? Who can point to where I start?
section.rac_body-text: As you read the chart, use one Two-Color Counter to represent each kind of vegetable that is added to the soup.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the rabbits cooking? What do you think they will put in the soup?
How many rabbits are holding the peas? What will they do with the peas?
How many vegetables are in the soup now?
How many carrots do you see? How many vegetables are in the soup now?
What did the rabbits make? How many vegetables are there in all? How did the rabbits work together? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Find soup recipes on the Internet to make with the children. Identify safe recipe sites beforehand and show children a few different soup recipes. As an alternative, you can bring in cookbooks.

Provide paper and drawing or painting materials. Ask children to draw their own recipe, showing which ingredients they will use and the final dish. Invite volunteers to share and explain their recipes with the group.
Provide a writing prompt asking how the story shows the rabbits working together.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Digital tools can complement academic instruction in the classroom when they are used appropriately. Allow children to explore devices containing age-appropriate interactive media to reinforce what you are teaching in class.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss sources of light with children. Point out that windows let in the light from the sun, but do not make light.
Guide children to try to “catch the sky” by tossing a pretend ball to another child. Have them pass the imaginary sky around until each child has caught it.
Discuss the idea of opposites with children. Point out that Mole’s home is dark, and she wants it to be light. These are opposites of each other. Ask for the opposite of underground.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Mole Catches the Sky by Ellen Tarlow and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki one more time.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We have learned about how Mole’s friends tried to bring the sky into her home. When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the animals work together?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together, this time with volunteers acting out how the animals worked together.
First, let’s all pretend we are holding the book and reading. How do we hold a book when we read it? What do we do when we finish a page?
Describe Mole’s house. What do you think it would be like if the animals brought her light, warmth, and breeze?
Let’s pretend to be Mole and catch the sky with our claws. Use two hands as claws!
Let’s try to catch light in a nutshell like Squirrel. Let’s each fill five pretend nutshells.
Bird breathes in deep to hold air. Try to hold your breath while we count to three with our fingers.
What was Mole’s house like when she went to bed? What was it like when she woke up? How do the pictures in the story help give you information?
Why did the friends make a window for Mole? (MB)
How does Mole feel with her friends sitting around the table with her? Let’s act happy like Mole and her friends. (MB)
How do the animals work together?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then, ask several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They bring things to Mole’s house.
They let light, warmth, and a breeze into Mole’s house.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about what they would like to see out their window.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the animals work together to make?
The animals work together to make a w_____ (window).
The animals work together to make a window.
How does Mole feel about her window?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children pre-read the book by showing the pictures before reading aloud the text. Talk with children about what they expect the text will say and the clues they used to come to these conclusions. Review how the pictures relate to the story by asking children to say what is shown in the pictures.
